channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for OH

item.title: Report E-2024010520
item.description:
Report E-2024010520

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-02T15:12:00+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-25
  • City: Brewster
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Wheeling and Lake Erei Railway
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: I, John Vergis Hazardous Materials Officer for the WLE, was called by the WLE Brewster Yardmaster at 0130 hrs. on 1-25-2024 for a report of leaking tank car GATZX 80031. When I arrived to look at the car, I noticed that the car was leaking from the breadbox cover. I removed seal #0000823 and opened the lid to find that the leak was coming from the Apollo Liquid Valve. I saw that the valve stem nut was backed off the stem and that the valve handle was not secured tight to the stem anymore. It looked like when someone tried to tighten the valve, that is did not close all the way because the valve handle did not fit properly since it was loose. I applied the handle back on the stem and tried closing the valve. The valve did then close and the leak stopped. The liquid was leaking from out of the valve plug which was not tight. I tried to tighten the valve stem nut but I could not get it to tighten. I backed off the nut completely and found that someone tried installing a course thread nut onto a fine thread valve stem. That is why the nut would not tighten down onto the handle. I then tried installing a fine thread nut and I was able to get it to tighten down. I felt that is was a good fix. I then removed the plug from the valve since it was leaking and found that there was no thread tape on the threads that were screwed into the valve. There was a build up of old tape on the top portion of the threads but not on the threads that would actually seal. Installed new thread sealant and tightened the valve plug. I then closed the breadbox lid and inatalled new seal #0000229. I then released the car for transportation.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: CERTIFIED PERSONNEL CALLED ABOUT A WET DENTED METAL DRUM/PAIL THAT WAS LEAKING AT THE BASE. DRUM WAS PLACED IN A LINED TOTE AND TAKEN TO HMPA FOR PROCESSING. DescribePack: MISHANDLING AT PREVIOUS LOAD POINT ALLOWED BOTTOM OF METAL PAIL TO BECOME DENTED CAUSING WELD AT BASE TO FAIL AND LIQUID RELEASE TO OCCUR. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: METAL PAIL/DRUM WAS PLACED IN A LINED TOTE.

item.title: Report E-2024010475
item.description:
Report E-2024010475

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-30T15:10:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-23
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 23, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon jerrican of UN2922 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel utilized cleaners and absorbent pads to the wheel cleaner-impacted dock floor. All spent absorbent pads and broken down pallet were collected and containerized into one (1) 35-gallon drum and the damaged jug was laced into a separate 35-gallon drum. Both were set aside for future disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024010469
item.description:
Report E-2024010469

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-30T15:10:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-22
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 22, 2024, one (1) 500-pound cylinder of UN1009 was hissing when moved and covered in ice. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to inspect the cylinder and remediate the site. TLE personnel inspected the cylinder for any punctures or damage. No damage was found. Crews observed the cylinder was off gassing, creating a reaction. TLE personnel utilized hand tools, and absorbent pads, to remove ice from the frozen cylinder. Crews then moved the cylinder to the OS&D heat room, so the cylinder could gently warm up, and continue to release all of its contents. TLE personnel verified the cylinder released all of its contents and finished off gassing. Crews estimated 186 pounds of gas released. TLE personnel recommended the cylinder warm up a few hours before sending it for continued processing and shipping. All Ansul Halon 1301 (UN1009) impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 5-gallon pail and R+L personnel took possession of the waste to be added to the facility waste stream.

item.title: Report E-2024010447
item.description:
Report E-2024010447

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-29T15:11:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-24
  • City: COLUMBUS
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XCO experienced a UN3264 Kroff KR-B3020 release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 100-gallons of product released to an 8’ x 20’ area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Sodium bicarb and absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area to clean and neutralize the release. The impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were then collected and containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized into an 85-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024010479
item.description:
Report E-2024010479

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-30T15:10:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-26
  • City: SHEFFIELD VILLAGE
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: KAG SPECIALTY PRODUCTS GROUP, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The KAG Specialty Products Group, LLC driver was attempting to deliver nitric acid into the customer's storage tank. A defective gasket allowed approximately 2 gallons of nitric acid to be released. Hepaco Environmental responded to the scene and handled the remediation.
